73: The first building constructed on CMU's campus was the University Club building, which was completed in 1904. The building was designed by architect Henry Hornbostel and was originally used as a men's club. In 1914, the building was converted into a women's dormitory and was renamed the University Club Annex. The building was later renamed the University Club Dormitory and was used as a women's dormitory until 1981. In 1982, the building was converted into a co-ed dormitory and was renamed the University Club Residence Hall. The building was again renamed in 2000 and is now known as the University Club Apartments.

78: The University of Pittsburgh's athletic teams, referred to as the " Pittsburgh Panthers " or "Pitt Panthers", include 19 university-sponsored varsity teams at the highest level of competitive collegiate athletics in the United States: the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) Division I (NCAA Division 1 Football Bowl Subdivision (FBS)). [ 255 ] Varsity men's sports sponsored by the university are baseball, basketball, cross country, football, soccer, swimming and diving, indoor track and field, outdoor track and field, and wrestling ; while sponsored women's varsity sports include basketball, cross country, gymnastics, lacrosse, soccer, softball, swimming and diving, indoor track and field, outdoor track and field, and volleyball. [ 256 ] All varsity sports teams compete as members of the Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC) since the 2013–14 season, with the exception of the gymnastics team which moved to the ACC when the conference began sponsoring the sport in 2023. [ 257 ] The university also maintains membership in the Eastern College Athletic Conference (ECAC). [ 258 ] Pitt athletes have received a total of five Olympic medals. 100: Tartan Racing is a collaboration between Carnegie Mellon and General Motors Corporation that competes in the DARPA Grand Challenge. The Grand Challenge is a competition for driverless cars sponsored by Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA). Tartan Racing is led by Carnegie Mellon roboticist William L. "Red" Whittaker. [12] In 2007, Tartan Racing won the DARPA Urban Challenge, in which 11 autonomous ground vehicles raced over urban roadways. In the challenge, team vehicles were required to obey all California driving laws, share the road with other drivers and robotic cars, and complete the course in under six hours. Tartan Racing won the $2 million cash prize with Boss, a reworked 2007 Chevy Tahoe. Averaging about 14 miles (23 km) an hour for a 55-mile (89 km) trip, Boss beat the second-place team, Stanford Racing, by just under 20 minutes. 117: Randy Pausch was a professor of computer science, human-computer interaction and design. Pausch was also a best-selling author, who became known around the world after he gave "The Last Lecture" speech on September 18, 2007 at Carnegie Mellon. Pausch was instrumental in the development of Alice, a computer teaching tool. He also co-founded Carnegie Mellon's Entertainment Technology Center. Randy Pausch died on July 25, 2008. Shaw published seminal work on software engineering, and has lately become well known for her work on computer science
119: The uncertainty principle is a fundamental limit to knowledge in quantum mechanics, expressed in terms of the standard deviation of position and momentum. It states that the more precisely the position of some particle is determined, the less precisely its momentum can be known, and vice versa. The originator of the uncertainty principle is generally acknowledged to be Werner Heisenberg, who first wrote the principle down in 1927. [ 1 ] [ 2 ] [ 3 ] The first fully rigorous proof was given by John von Neumann, [ 4 ] although it was also later given in 1930 by F. J. M. Cottingham. [ 5 ] The uncertainty principle is one of the pillars of the quantum revolution in physics, and has been called "the single most important rule in all of science". [ 6 ] It is also one of the most misunderstood and misinterpreted scientific principles. The uncertainty principle is not a statement about the fact that measurement devices are necessarily inaccurate, but about the fundamental properties of nature. It is a consequence of the wave nature of matter. A wave can have any position, and a wave can have any momentum, but it cannot have a precisely defined position and a precisely defined momentum. The uncertainty principle can be derived from the commutation
121: The championship game of the National Football League pursued by Pittsburgh's NFL team is the Super Bowl.
132: The Dietrich College of Humanities and Social Sciences (DC) is the liberal and professional studies college and the second-largest academic unit by enrollment at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA. The college emphasizes study through rigorous analysis and technology of the behaviors, institutions, and beliefs that constitute the human experience, describing itself as “not an ordinary liberal arts school. ” The college was named for Marianna Brown Dietrich, the mother of philanthropist William S. Dietrich II, after his donation of $265 million to the university in 2011 – the largest single donation in Carnegie Mellon history. The Dietrich College offers more than 60 majors and minors through its academic departments and specialized degree programs. About the Dietrich College The College of Humanities and Social Sciences admitted its first freshman class in 1969, following the announcement of the pending closure of the Margaret Morrison Carnegie College, although roots of the college can be traced to the Division of Applied Psychology, founded in 1915 and led by Walter Van Dyke Bingham and Walter Dill Scott as the first research-oriented department within Carnegie Mellon. The administrative offices of the Dietrich College are located in Baker Hall. Most of the classes offered by the Dietrich College are held in Baker Hall and Porter Hall, but
